stem: The patient's condition is rapidly deteriorating. Based on the assessment data, determine whether each intervention is indicated, contraindicated, or not relevant at this time.

itemContext.sbar: S: Jameson Walker, 58-year-old male in ICU, is rapidly declining. B: Admitted at 04:00 for pneumonia; history of Type 2 Diabetes (non-compliant with diet, managed with oral hypoglycemics). A: At 11:00, patient unresponsive to verbal stimuli, exhibiting Kussmaul respirations and fruity breath. Vitals: HR 130 bpm, BP 90/60 mmHg, RR 36, Temp 38.9°C (102°F), SpO2 92% on 2L NC. Labs: Glucose 650 mg/dL, pH 7.2, HCO3 10 mEq/L, positive serum ketones, TSH <0.01 mIU/L, Free T4 >6 ng/dL. Patient is agitated and diaphoretic. R: STAT orders for insulin drip, fluids, and electrolyte replacement are in place. Concerns include Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) complicated by possible thyroid storm. Droplet precautions are in effect for pneumonia. Requesting immediate guidance on optimal management.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content: S: Jameson Walker, 58-year-old male in ICU, is rapidly declining. B: Admitted at 04:00 for pneumonia; history of Type 2 Diabetes (non-compliant with diet, managed with oral hypoglycemics). A: At 11:00, patient unresponsive to verbal stimuli, exhibiting Kussmaul respirations and fruity breath. Vitals: HR 130 bpm, BP 90/60 mmHg, RR 36, Temp 38.9°C (102°F), SpO2 92% on 2L NC. Labs: Glucose 650 mg/dL, pH 7.2, HCO3 10 mEq/L, positive serum ketones, TSH <0.01 mIU/L, Free T4 >6 ng/dL. Patient is agitated and diaphoretic. R: STAT orders for insulin drip, fluids, and electrolyte replacement are in place. Concerns include Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) complicated by possible thyroid storm. Droplet precautions are in effect for pneumonia. Requesting immediate guidance on optimal management.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Scheduled:
Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h
Metformin 500mg PO BID (hold per orders)
PRN:
Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for fever (last given 06:00)
New Orders:
Regular Insulin IV drip (protocol order)
0.9% Normal Saline 1L bolus
Potassium Chloride 40 mEq IV piggyback

rationale.correct: Insulin administration is crucial in DKA to facilitate glucose uptake into cells and correct metabolic acidosis. IV fluids (0.9% Normal Saline) address severe dehydration from osmotic diuresis in DKA and hypermetabolism in thyroid storm. Potassium replacement is necessary as insulin shifts potassium intracellularly, risking hypokalemia. Beta-blockers (e.g., Propranolol) manage tachycardia, arrhythmias, and adrenergic symptoms of thyroid storm. Cooling blankets manage hyperthermia from thyroid storm and infection. Propylthiouracil (PTU) inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis, a key intervention in thyroid storm.
rationale.incorrect: Dextrose is contraindicated initially in DKA due to already high glucose levels; it's used later if hypoglycemia occurs from insulin. Antipyretics alone are insufficient for severe hyperthermia compounded by thyroid storm. Sodium bicarbonate is generally avoided unless pH is <7.0 due to risks of rebound alkalosis and cerebral edema. Increasing oxygen flow may be needed if SpO2 doesn't improve, but it's not primary. Diuretics are contraindicated due to existing severe dehydration from DKA.
clinicalPearls: Monitor potassium levels closely during insulin administration in DKA.
Recognize overlapping symptoms of DKA and thyroid storm for timely intervention.
Early beta-blocker administration improves outcomes in thyroid storm.

questionTrap.trap: The trap is focusing solely on DKA or thyroid storm, overlooking the potential concurrent condition. Elevated temperature and thyroid hormone levels suggest a combined presentation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Review all labs and vitals, considering both DKA and thyroid storm criteria. Prioritize interventions addressing both conditions.

mnemonic.title: S.T.O.R.M.
mnemonic.expansion: Surgery/Stress, Thyroid hormone increase, Oxygen demand increase, Rapid heart rate, Malignant hyperthermia (fever)
